lib package¶

Submodules¶

lib.CommandLine module¶

This program contains the command line UI for the ORMPY program.

lib.CommandLine.check_or_populate(model, args)[source]¶

Check or populate the model, as requested.

lib.CommandLine.configure_logger(args)[source]¶

Configure the logger.

lib.CommandLine.execute(arglist=None)[source]¶

Command line entry point for ORMPY program. Use the arglist parameter to provide an argument list manually (i.e. not via sys.argv).

lib.CommandLine.import_model(path)[source]¶

Import the request ORM model and return it.

lib.CommandLine.parse_args(arglist=None)[source]¶

Parse command line arguments and return an args object. To provide an argument list manually (i.e. not from sys.argv), use the arglist parameter.

lib.Constraint module¶

This module provides a class for ORM constraints.

Object type this constraint identifies

min_freq = None¶

A uniqueness constraint is a special case of a frequency constraint in which the min and max frequencies are both 1

class lib.Constraint.ValueConstraint(uid=None, name=None)[source]¶

Bases: lib.Constraint.Constraint

A value constraint. This implementation supports only a limited form of value constraint: specifically, enumerations (i.e. min value == max value), bounded integer ranges, or a combination of the two. For example:

Supported:

  • {‘Dog’, ‘Cat’, ‘Monkey’}
  • {1..25, 20..30}
  • {1.54, 1.78, 1.99}
  • {2001/12/31, 2002/02/13}
  • {‘Dog’, 1..25, ‘Cat’, 1.45, 20..30}

Not supported:

  • Range of text values: {‘Dog’..’Donna’}
  • Unbounded integer range: {>1}
  • Invalid range: {3..2}
  • Range of float values: {3.6..3.7}
MAX_SIZE = 1000¶

Arbitrary, for performance.

add_range(min_value, max_value=None, min_open=False, max_open=False)[source]¶

Add a range of values to the constraint.

domain = None¶

Domain of valid values

size[source]¶

The number of items in the domain defined by the constraint.

exception lib.Constraint.ValueConstraintError[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

An exception raised by an invalid value constraint.

lib.Domain module¶

The Domain.py module implements the domains that underly types. More specifically, classes in the module provide a means to generate a set of values conforming to a particular data type. For example:

my_int = IntegerDomain()
first10 = my_int.draw(10)

The above code defines a domain of unsigned integers and then returns the first 10 integers from that domain as a set.

class lib.Domain.BoolDomain[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain for boolean (True/False) values.

class lib.Domain.DateDomain(start=datetime.date(2000, 1, 1))[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain for date values. Generated dates start on <start> which defaults to January 1, 2000.

class lib.Domain.DateTimeDomain(start=datetime.datetime(2000, 1, 1, 0, 0))[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain for datetime values. Generated datetimes start on <start> which defaults to January 1, 2000 at midnight and increment by minutes.

class lib.Domain.Domain(max_size=9223372036854775807)[source]¶

Bases: object

A domain, which can be used to generate a set of values conforming to a data type.

draw(n)[source]¶

Draw the first n elements from the domain and return as a list. If n is larger than the number of elements in the domain, the entire domain is returned as a list.

max_size = None¶

Maximum number of elements permitted by the domain. By default, the maximum is sys.maxsize.

class lib.Domain.EnumeratedDomain[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain whose values are explicitly provided by the caller.

add(elements)[source]¶

Add an element or list of elements to the domain.

max_size[source]¶

Maximum size of the domain, which for an enumerated domain is just the size of the underlying list (i.e. max_size answers the question, what is the largest possible number of items to draw from the domain?).

size[source]¶

Size of the enumerated domain.

class lib.Domain.FloatDomain[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A floating point domain. Only includes floating point numbers in increments of 0.1 (e.g. 0.0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, etc.).

class lib.Domain.IntegerDomain[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain containing unsigned integers.

class lib.Domain.StringDomain(prefix='')[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain for string values. The constructor includes a prefix parameter. Generated strings are of the form ‘prefix<n>’ where <n> is a monotonically increasing unsigned integer.

class lib.Domain.TimeDomain(start=datetime.time(0, 0))[source]¶

Bases: lib.Domain.Domain

A domain for time values. Generated times start at <start> which defaults to midnight and increments by minutes.

lib.InequalitySystem module¶

Module for creating and solving systems of inequalities of the simple form permitted by ORM–. Specifically, all inequalities are of one of two forms:

  • c * x <= y_1 + y_2 + ... + y_n
  • c * x <= y_1 * y_2 * ... * y_n
class lib.InequalitySystem.Constant(value)[source]¶

Bases: lib.InequalitySystem.Variable

Represents a constant.

class lib.InequalitySystem.Expression(var_list)[source]¶

Bases: list

A restricted expression over a list of variables. The expression is restricted in the sense that it permits only one type of operator — e.g. x + y + z, or x * y * x. This is an abstract class and should not be instantiated directly. Subclasses modify the self._op and self._sym attributes to define the expression type.

Parameters:var_list – list of lib.InequalitySystem.Variable
result()[source]¶

Evaluates the operator on the list of variables.

tostring()[source]¶

Returns the expression as a string for display.

class lib.InequalitySystem.Inequality(lhs, rhs, coeff=1)[source]¶

Bases: object

An inequality of the form:

coeff * lhs <= rhs

where rhs is one of the following forms:

  • y_1 + y_2 + ... + y_n [i.e. a lib.InequalitySystem.Sum]
  • y_1 * y_2 * ... * y_n [i.e. a lib.InequalitySystem.Product]
Parameters:
  • lhs – Left-hand side. A lib.InequalitySystem.Variable
  • rhs – Right-hand side. A lib.InequalitySystem.Expression
  • coeff – Coefficient on left-hand side of inequality.
evaluate()[source]¶

Evaluates right-hand side of inequality and updates candidate value of left-hand side.

tostring()[source]¶

Returns inequality as a string for display or debugging.

variables()[source]¶

Returns the list of lib.InequalitySystem.Variable in the inequality.

class lib.InequalitySystem.InequalitySystem[source]¶

Bases: list

A system of lib.InequalitySystem.Inequality inequalities.

add(inequality)[source]¶

Add an inequality to the system.

Parameters:inequality – A lib.InequalitySystem.Inequality
solve(debug=False)[source]¶

Solve the system. If there is a solution, returns a dictionary whose keys are the names of the variables in the system and whose values are the corresponding values in the solution. If there is no solution, returns None.

class lib.InequalitySystem.Product(thelist)[source]¶

Bases: lib.InequalitySystem.Expression

tostring()[source]¶

Returns the expression as a string for display.

class lib.InequalitySystem.Sum(thelist)[source]¶

Bases: lib.InequalitySystem.Expression

Represents a sum of variables.

class lib.InequalitySystem.Variable(name, lower=1, upper=9223372036854775807)[source]¶

Bases: lib.InequalitySystem.Expression

Represents a variable with an upper and lower bound.

declare_less_than(value)[source]¶

Update candidate if it is greater than value. Called whenever a variable’s upper bound is potentially changed by evaluating an inequality.

is_invalid()[source]¶

Returns true if variable bounds are invalid.

is_stable()[source]¶

Returns true if variable is in a stable state.

lower = None¶

Lower bound for the variable

name = None¶

Variable name

result()[source]¶

Override Expression.result.

tostring()[source]¶

Return variable upper bound as a string.

update()[source]¶

Update upper bound and status based on candidate value. Called for each variable in the system after a complete iteration of evaluating the inequalities in the system.

upper = None¶

Upper bound for the variable

lib.JoinPath module¶

The JoinPath module implements the JoinPath class and supporting classes.

class lib.JoinPath.Join(role1, role2)[source]¶

Bases: object

A join is a tuple of roles on which two fact types will be joined. The roles must be played by compatible object types.

class lib.JoinPath.JoinPath(init_role)[source]¶

Bases: object

A join path specifies the inner join of two or more fact types.

extend(role1, role2)[source]¶

Extend the join path by joining role1 (which should be part of a fact type already on the path) with role2.

materialize()[source]¶

Executes the joins along the join path and returns the resulting join fact type. The join fact type will be covered by copies of the same kinds of constraints that cover the fact types along the path.

lib.Model module¶

Model.py provides a class to store a simplified ORM model consisting of a set of object types, a set of fact types, and a set of constraints.

class lib.Model.Model[source]¶

Bases: object

object_types = None¶

The set of object types in the model (lib.ObjectType.ObjectTypeSet)

lib.ModelElement module¶

ModelElement.py provides an abstract class for a model element (a generic element in a model from which an object type, fact type, and constraint can be derived) as well as an abstract class for a set of model elements.

class lib.ModelElement.ModelElement(uid=None, name=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

An abstract element in an ORM model.

name[source]¶

Unique name for the model element. Cannot be changed after the model element is created.

uid[source]¶

Unique identifier for the model element. Cannot be changed after the model element is created.

class lib.ModelElement.ModelElementSet(name='Model Elements')[source]¶

Bases: object

A set of model elements.

add(element)[source]¶

Add an element to the set. If the name exists in the set, rename the element by adding an integer suffix to make it unique in the set. For example, if an element named Person is added three times, the set will contain Person, Person2, and Person3.

count()[source]¶

Returns the number of items in the set.

display()[source]¶

Display the set of elements to stdout.

get(name)[source]¶

Retrieve an element by name. Returns None if the element is not in the set.

name = None¶

The name of the set. May be used for display, etc.

lib.NormaLoader module¶

Module for importing .orm files produced by the NORMA modeling tool, which is a plugin for Visual Studio.

NormaLoader.py has been tested on the .orm file format that utilizes the following namespaces:

  • ormRoot: http://schemas.neumont.edu/ORM/2006-04/ORMRoot
  • orm: http://schemas.neumont.edu/ORM/2006-04/ORMCore

Omissions: NormaLoader intentionally ignores much of the .orm file structure when loading the file into a lib.Model.Model object (much of the .orm file is not relevant to the analyses performed by ORMPY). All information outside of the <orm:ORMModel> node is ignored, which includes things like diagram (shape) data and extensions. NormaLoader also ignores the following (not necessarily exhaustive) list of items:

  • Sample (instance) data
  • Model elements not explicitly modeled by the modeler (implicit elements)
  • Model errors reported by NORMA
  • Informal model notes
  • Multiple readings for a fact type
  • Derivation rules for subtypes, fact types, and roles
  • Constraints outside the scope of ORM– or its extensions
  • Culture-invariant form of value constraints

A list of important model elements (such as derivations and constraints) that are ignored by NormaLoader is contained in the omissions attribute after loading the input file.

Data Types: NormaLoader maps each data type specified in the .orm file to a subclass of lib.Domain.Domain. NormaLoader ignores the length and scale facets specified in the .orm file.

class lib.NormaLoader.NormaLoader(filename)[source]¶

Bases: object

Loads an .orm file produced by the NORMA modeling tool into a lib.Model.Model. There are no public methods in this class. An .orm file can be loaded via the constructor. For example:

loader = NormaLoader("/path/to/file/example.orm")
model = loader.model
model = None¶

The ORM model (lib.Model.Model) loaded from the .orm file.

omissions = None¶

List of items in the .orm file omitted by the NormaLoader

lib.ORMMinusModel module¶

Module to implement an ORM- model, which is a restricted form of an ORM model that can be checked for satisfiability and populated in polynomial time.

class lib.ORMMinusModel.ORMMinusModel(model=None, ubound=15)[source]¶

Bases: object

An ORM- model along with its solution. The solution is computed using the ORM- satisfiability algorithm (Smaragdakis et al.).

Parameters:
  • model – The corresponding lib.Model.Model
  • ubound – Upper bound on the size of model elements in the solution
DEFAULT_SIZE = 15¶

Default upper bound on model element cardinalities.

constraints = None¶

Constraints

fact_types = None¶

Fact types

get_parts(fact_type)[source]¶

Get the non-overlapping roles and internal frequency constraints that comprise a fact type.

ignored = None¶

List of ignored constraints

object_types = None¶

Object types

lib.ObjectType module¶

ObjectType.py provides classes for the various object types in ORM: entity type, value type, and objectified type.

An entity type is an object type that requires identification.

lib.Population module¶

Module to generate a population of an ORMMinusModel.

class lib.Population.Population(model)[source]¶

Bases: object

A population of an ORMMinusModel. If the model is satisfiable, then self.object_types and self.fact_types will contain the populations of objects and facts, respectively, that satisfy the constraints in the model. For an unsatisfiable model, Popuation() will raise a ValueError exception.

fact_types = None¶

A dictionary of fact type populations. Specifically, the key is the fact type name and the value is a lib.Population.Relation.

object_types = None¶

A dictionary of object type populations. Specifically, the key is the object type name and the value is a list of objects.

write_csv(dirname)[source]¶

Write the entire population to CSV files stored in a directory (one file per object type or fact type).

write_stdout()[source]¶

Writes entire population to stdout.

class lib.Population.Relation(names=[])[source]¶

Bases: list

A relation, which is a list of lists of identical arity.

add(tupl)[source]¶

Add tuple to the list. The ordering of elements in the tuple is assumed to match the order of self.names.

arity = None¶

Number of columns in the relation

combine_with(target, n)[source]¶

Combine self with a target relation according to the enumeration algorithm of Smaragdakis, et al.

names = None¶

List of names of each column in the relation

lib.Population.lcm(a, b)[source]¶

Return the least common multiple of a and b.

lib.TestDataLocator module¶

Locates test data directory without resorting to environment variable.

lib.TestDataLocator.get_data_dir()[source]¶

Return test data directory. See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2632199/how-do-i-get-the-path-of-

the-current-executed-file-in-python/2632297#2632297

Module contents¶

The lib package is the main library of Python modules for ORMPY.
